   Troponin-T:102/3/0.05, ALT / AST:[**11-25**], Alk Phos / T Bili:107/0.6,
   Amylase / Lipase:90/, Differential-Neuts:75.9 %, Lymph:6.9 %, Mono:7.3
   %, Eos:9.6 %, D-dimer:980 ng/mL, Fibrinogen:760 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:0.6
   mmol/L, Albumin:2.8 g/dL, LDH:199 IU/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL,
   PO4:3.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 58-year-old man with history of
   congenital heart disease and repairs in [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status
   post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic
   bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the
   tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin and multiple
   GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for continued management of heart
   failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.
   - consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - wean vent as tolerated
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TTE results
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u final CXR
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - consult pulmonary in am
   - non-contrast chest CT
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .
   CODE: full code (per OSH documentation)-need confirmation
   .
   COMM: Proxy name: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3676**] [**Known lastname **]  Relationship: brother  Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10805**]
   .
   Nutrition: tube feed consult
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2201-10-14**] 12:34 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2201-10-14**] 12:37 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

   Code status: Full code

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, repairs, and subsequent valve replacements. He is currently in the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. He is on ventilatory support, and his vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 111/56 mmHg. His respiratory status is improving, with a PCO2 of 60 and a bicarbonate level of 40.

The patient's hemodynamic status is also unstable, with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 14 mmHg, and his cardiac output is uncertain due to the presence of a VSD and PFO. His troponin levels are normal, and there is no evidence of cardiac infarction. His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL, and his urine output is decreased.

The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension, and his pulmonary artery pressure is elevated. He is also at risk for infective endocarditis due to his prosthetic valves.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.6-11.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 33.0-36.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 162-181 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.05 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 199 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.0 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic hypercarbia and potential worsening of his pulmonary hypertension
* Cardiac failure due to the patient's underlying cardiac condition and potential worsening of his mitral and pulmonic valve regurgitation
* Infective endocarditis due to the patient's prosthetic valves
* Renal failure due to the patient's impaired renal function and potential worsening of his underlying cardiac condition
* Bleeding due to the patient's thrombocytopenia and potential worsening of his coagulopathy
* Hypovolemia due to the patient's recent diuresis and potential worsening of his cardiac output

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue ventilatory support and wean as tolerated
* Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust his fluid management accordingly
* Consider placement of a PA catheter or right heart catheter to better assess the patient's cardiac output and pulmonary pressures
* Continue antibiotics and monitor for signs of infection
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly
* Consider consultation with cardiothoracic surgery to assess the patient's valve integrity and potential need for valve replacement
* Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust his platelet transfusion plan accordingly
* Consider consultation with a pulmonologist to assess the patient's respiratory status and potential need for bronchodilators or other respiratory therapies.

   congenital heart disease and repairs in [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status
   post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic
   bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the
   tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin and multiple
   GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for continued management of heart
   failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.
   - consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - wean vent as tolerated
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TTE results
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u final CXR
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - consult pulmonary in am
   - non-contrast chest CT
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .

   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .

   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a complex medical history, including congenital heart disease, heart failure, diabetes, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, blood pressure of 111/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and his central venous pressure is 14 mmHg.

The patient has several potential medical complications that require close monitoring and management. These include:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia is likely due to chronic respiratory disease, and the acute exacerbation may be related to heart failure or oxygen narcosis. Further management includes weaning ventilation, considering a pulmonary artery catheter, and monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Hypotension: The etiology of the patient's hypotension is unclear, but it may be related to heart failure, hypovolemia, or overdiuresis. Management includes weaning vasopressors, administering fluid boluses, and monitoring for signs of hypoperfusion.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient has a history of grossly bloody material from his endotracheal tube, which may be related to pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis, or cancer. Further management includes obtaining a final chest X-ray, sputum culture, and gram stain, and consulting pulmonology.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension may be related to his congenital heart disease or worsening VSD or mitral regurgitation. Further management includes monitoring for signs of right ventricular failure and considering a pulmonary artery catheter.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of chronic atrial fibrillation requires close monitoring and management, including anticoagulation and rate control.
6. Renal insufficiency: The patient's baseline creatinine is unknown, but his current creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, and his urine electrolytes are consistent with pre-renal etiology. Further management includes monitoring for signs of worsening renal function and avoiding nephrotoxins.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's absolute eosinophilia may be related to a drug eruption, and further management includes monitoring for signs of allergic reactions and considering corticosteroids.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's resolved thrombocytopenia may be related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and further management includes monitoring for signs of bleeding and considering platelet transfusions.
9. Anemia: The patient's history of anemia and current bleeding may be related to gastrointestinal bleeding, and further management includes monitoring for signs of bleeding and considering transfusions.
10. Diabetes: The patient's apparent diet-controlled diabetes requires close monitoring and management, including follow-up with his primary care physician.

In conclusion, the patient requires close monitoring and management for several potential medical complications, including hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, renal insufficiency, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and diabetes. Further management includes weaning ventilation, administering fluid boluses, monitoring for signs of respiratory failure, and consulting pulmonology, cardiology, and nephrology as necessary.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a complex medical history, including congenital heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil percentage, indicating an inflammatory response
* Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), suggesting an active inflammatory process
* Elevated troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac injury or infarction
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and creatine kinase (CK) levels, suggesting possible cardiac or muscular damage
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels, indicating possible kidney dysfunction
* Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia, suggesting possible electrolyte imbalance
* Eosinophilia, indicating possible allergic or hypersensitivity reaction

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to chronic pulmonary hypertension and possible pneumonia
* Hypotension, possibly due to hypovolemia, septic shock, or cardiogenic shock
* Hemoptysis, possibly due to pneumonia, bronchiectasis, or pulmonary arteriovenous malformation
* Chronic atrial fibrillation, requiring anticoagulation
* Pulmonary hypertension, likely worsening due to congenital heart disease and possible valvular deterioration
* Right ventricular failure, possibly due to pulmonary hypertension, valvular deterioration, or cardiac infarction
* Chronic kidney disease, possibly due to hypertension, diabetes, or chronic heart failure

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia
* Dopamine and levophed for hemodynamic support
* Heparin for anticoagulation
* Coumadin for atrial fibrillation
* Lipitor for hyperlipidemia
* Abilify for depression and anxiety

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure, possibly due to worsening pulmonary hypertension or pneumonia
* Cardiac arrest, possibly due to cardiogenic shock or arrhythmia
* Sepsis, possibly due to MRSA pneumonia or other bacterial infections
* Acute kidney injury, possibly due to hypovolemia or septic shock
* Electrolyte imbalance, possibly due to hypocalcemia or hypomagnesemia
* Bleeding, possibly due to thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Bronchoscopy to diagnose and treat pneumonia
* Pulmonary vasodilators to manage pulmonary hypertension
* Cardiac medications to manage heart failure and arrhythmia
* Antimicrobial therapy to treat MRSA pneumonia
* Fluid management to prevent hypovolemia and hypotension
* Monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to track the patient's progress and identify potential complications.

   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a complex medical history, including congenital heart disease, repairs, and replacements of valves, and chronic conditions such as heart failure, diabetes, and chronic atrial fibrillation.

The patient was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. The patient's condition is unstable, and multiple medical complications are possible.

   flow. The right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with moderate
   global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic root is moderately dilated at

   Right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall hypokinesis. Severe
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Moderate to severe tricuspid
   regurgitation. Slightly increased pulmonic bioprosthetic gradient.
   Normal functioning mitral bioprosthesis.
   CT CHEST:
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No evidence for diffuse systemic lung disease such as interstitial
   lung disease. No fibrosis. No significant pulmonary edema.
   2. Small pleural effusions with relatively out of proportion bibasal
   atelectasis. This atelectasis could certainly compromise the limited
   reserve of this patient. Pneumonia may also coexist in this atelectatic
   lung.
   3. Right pulmonary artery dilatation compresses mainstem bronchi
   particulary onthe right which may also contribute to the limtied
   reserve.
   4. Pattern of ground glass nodulrity can be seen in primary pulmonary
   hypertension.
   5. Spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe. Recommend followup chest
   CT in three months.
   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is possible, compression of mainstem
   bronchous.
   - Pulm will bronch in AM
 possible NO later.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TSH, vanc lvl (target 3 wks of vanc treatment).
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry (i/o even)
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u CXR am
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - pulmonary bronch in am
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries, including replacement of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of a ventricular septal defect, and repair of the tricuspid valve. He is currently admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is on coumadin. His current medications include vancomycin, fentanyl, dopamine, and norepinephrine.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a baseline hypercarbia and acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has a history of pulmonary hypertension and is on oxygen therapy at home. His oxygen saturation is 97% on room air, but he requires mechanical ventilation to improve his oxygenation.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also concerning, with a history of congestive heart failure and a recent echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressure and moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation. His blood pressure is 105/48 mmHg, and he is receiving dopamine and norepinephrine infusions to support his blood pressure.

The patient's hemodynamic status is concerning, with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 16 mmHg and a pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) showing elevated pulmonary artery pressure. His cardiac output is estimated to be 2.5 L/min, and his systemic vascular resistance (SVR) is elevated.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with a white blood cell count (WBC) of 8.6, a hemoglobin (Hb) of 10.2 g/dL, and a platelet count (PLT) of 162,000/μL. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium (K+) level of 4.1 mEq/L, a sodium (Na+) level of 142 mEq/L, and a chloride (Cl-) level of 96 mEq/L. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 32 mg/dL, and his creatinine (Cr) level is 1.8 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for a history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He is also taking medications for his atrial fibrillation, including warfarin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypercarbic respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure if not adequately treated.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of congestive heart failure and recent echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressure and moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation increases his risk of cardiac failure.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to a variety of causes, including pneumonia, bronchiectasis, pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, or cancer.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to a variety of causes, including cardiac failure, sepsis, or hemorrhage.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to a variety of causes, including sepsis, bleeding, or medication side effects.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to a variety of causes, including bleeding, chronic disease, or medication side effects.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be due to a variety of causes, including diuretic therapy, congestive heart failure, or nephrotic syndrome.
8. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be due to a variety of causes, including medication side effects, allergic reactions, or parasitic infections.
9. Thrombosis: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and recent echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressure increases his risk of thrombosis.
10. Infection: The patient's history of sepsis and recent echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressure increases his risk of infection.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory, cardiovascular, and hemodynamic status to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient, a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and repairs, is admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and respiratory failure. He has a baseline hypercarbic respiratory failure, which worsens with a recent MRSA pneumonia. He also has hypotension, possibly due to hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or hemotypsis.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including:

1. Fluid bolus and diuresis management to address hypotension and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
2. Antibiotics for MRSA pneumonia, with vancomycin started for 3 weeks.
3. Cardiovascular support with dopamine and levophed to maintain a mean arterial pressure of 60 mmHg.
4. Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation and bronchodilators.
5. Hemodynamic monitoring with central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) placement.

The patient's laboratory results show:

1. Elevated troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac injury.
2. Thrombocytopenia, which has resolved, with no evidence of bleeding.
3. Eosinophilia, possibly related to a drug eruption.
4. Anemia, with a history of anemia and currently bleeding.
5. Hyponatremia, possibly due to hypovolemia and recent diuresis.

The patient's radiology results show:

1. Chest CT scan with findings of small pleural effusions, bibasal atelectasis, and right pulmonary artery dilatation.
2. TTE (transesophageal echocardiogram) showing a muscular ventricular septal defect, right ventricular cavity enlargement, and moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: worsening heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and possible cardiac tamponade.
2. Respiratory complications: worsening hypercarbic respiratory failure, possible acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Hemodynamic instability: hypotension, possible cardiogenic shock, and vasopressor dependence.
4. Infection: MRSA pneumonia, possible sepsis, and catheter-related bloodstream infections.
5. Bleeding: possible bleeding complications from the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia.

In summary, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, and hemodynamic status to prevent potential complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a complex medical history, including congenital heart disease, multiple surgeries, and chronic conditions such as heart failure, diabetes, and pulmonary hypertension.

The patient is currently in the ICU due to acute respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. The note highlights several potential complications and considerations, including:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and oxygen dependence may have contributed to the acute respiratory failure. The etiology is unclear, but possible causes include CHF exacerbation, oxygen narcosis, or PE.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is unclear, but possible causes include hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or cardiogenic shock. The note suggests that the patient may have a VSD or mitral regurgitation contributing to the hypotension.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient has a history of grossly bloody material from the ET tube, which may be due to PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulmonary AVM, or cancer. The note suggests that the patient may have a pulmonary embolism or infarct.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension, which may be contributing to the respiratory failure and hypotension.
5. Congestive heart failure: The patient has a history of CHF, which may be exacerbated by the acute respiratory failure and hypotension.
6. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, which may be contributing to the hypotension and respiratory failure.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a history of thrombocytopenia, which may be contributing to the bleeding.
8. Eosinophilia: The patient has an absolute eosinophilia, which may be due to a drug eruption or allergic reaction.

The patient is currently receiving various treatments, including:

1. Ventilation: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation to support respiratory function.
2. Inotropic support: The patient is receiving dopamine and levophed to support blood pressure and cardiac function.
3. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia.
4. Diuretics: The patient is receiving diuretics to manage fluid overload and edema.
5. Anticoagulation: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT and PE.
6. Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management with fentanyl.
7. Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeding and nutrition consult.

The patient's future plans include:

1. Weaning from ventilation: The patient will be weaned from ventilation as tolerated.
2. Bronchoscopy: The patient will undergo bronchoscopy to evaluate the airways and assess for any potential causes of the hemoptysis.
3. Right heart catheterization: The patient may undergo right heart catheterization to evaluate cardiac function and hemodynamics.
4. Cardiac enzyme testing: The patient will undergo cardiac enzyme testing to evaluate for any signs of cardiac damage or infarction.
5. Echocardiogram: The patient will undergo an echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function and assess for any potential causes of the hypotension.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address the multiple complications and potential causes of the acute respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation.
* He is currently in the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.
* He has a muscular ventricular septal defect with bidirectional flow, right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall hypokinesis, and severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
* He is receiving mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, and vasopressors.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pulmonary Complications:**
	* Pneumonia or bronchitis may coexist with the patient's underlying lung disease.
	* The patient's severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension may worsen his respiratory failure.
2. **Cardiovascular Complications:**
	* Cardiogenic shock may occur due to worsening right ventricular failure or pulmonary hypertension.
	* Infective endocarditis could account for valvular deterioration.
	* The patient's history of chronic atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension increases his risk of stroke.
3. **Renal Complications:**
	* The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to hypovolemia, nephrotoxic medications, or underlying chronic kidney disease.
4. **Coagulation Complications:**
	* The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to bleeding, sepsis, or underlying bone marrow suppression.
	* His eosinophilia may be due to a drug eruption or underlying allergic reaction.
5. **Infectious Complications:**
	* The patient's MRSA-positive sputum culture suggests a potential respiratory tract infection.
	* The patient's history of chronic atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension increases his risk of endocarditis.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and inotropic support to manage the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular instability.
2. Monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolyte levels to prevent further worsening of his kidney function.
3. Consider placement of a pulmonary artery catheter to further assess the patient's hemodynamics.
4. Consult with a cardiologist and pulmonologist to optimize the patient's management.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulation profile and platelet count to prevent bleeding complications.
6. Consider antibiotic therapy for the patient's MRSA-positive sputum culture.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider bronchoscopy to evaluate for potential respiratory tract infections.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address his complex medical condition and prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # ARF: Cr now improving s/p fluid bolus.  Urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.
   - trend Cr
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now

   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding

   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c

   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He has chronic atrial fibrillation, heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. He has been treated with antibiotics, bronchodilators, and diuretics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and COPD make him prone to respiratory failure. The presence of pneumonia and pleural effusions may further compromise his respiratory status.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could be related to the pneumonia or other underlying infections.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and borderline RV failure make him susceptible to cardiac failure. The presence of hypotension and elevated PA pressures on echocardiogram suggest worsening RV failure.
4. Bleeding: The patient's hemoptysis and low platelet count suggest the possibility of bleeding, which could be related to the patient's anticoagulation therapy or underlying coagulopathy.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output suggest the possibility of acute kidney injury, which could be related to hypovolemia, sepsis, or nephrotoxic medications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hyponatremia and hypokalemia suggest the possibility of electrolyte imbalance, which could be related to diuretic therapy, hypovolemia, or other underlying conditions.
7. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusions suggest the possibility of infection, which could be related to aspiration, trauma, or underlying lung disease.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count suggests the possibility of thrombocytopenia, which could be related to sepsis, bone marrow suppression, or other underlying conditions.
9. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level suggests the possibility of anemia, which could be related to chronic disease, bleeding, or other underlying conditions.
10. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusions suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which could be related to aspiration, trauma, or underlying lung disease.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition make him susceptible to a variety of medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, cardiac failure, bleeding, renal failure, electrolyte imbalance, infection, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and pneumonia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-inch tall, 90.3 kg individual with a history of heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pulmonary hypertension. The patient was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, impaired skin integrity, and acute respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/38 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on a FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, indicating possible sepsis. The patient's liver function tests are within normal limits, but the albumin level is low, indicating malnutrition.

The patient's chest computed tomography (CT) scan shows small pleural effusions, bibasal atelectasis, and a spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe. The patient is receiving cefepime and vancomycin antibiotics for suspected pneumonia.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. The patient's oxygen delivery device is an endotracheal tube, and the ventilator mode is set to controlled mechanical ventilation (CMV) with assist and auto-flow.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient's skin is not assessed, and the peripheral vascular examination is incomplete.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's chest CT scan shows a spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe, and the patient is receiving antibiotics for suspected pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.
3. Heart failure: The patient has a history of heart failure and is receiving treatment for acute heart failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, indicating possible sepsis.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's albumin level is low, indicating malnutrition.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue antibiotics for suspected pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Continue treatment for acute heart failure.
4. Monitor the patient's laboratory results for signs of sepsis.
5. Provide nutrition support, including tube feedings and glycemic control.

The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is unknown.

   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # ARF: Cr now improving s/p fluid bolus.  Urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.
   - trend Cr
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .
   CODE: full code (per OSH documentation)-need confirmation
   .
   COMM: Proxy name: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3676**] [**Known lastname **]  Relationship: brother  Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10805**]
   .
   Nutrition: tube feed consult
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs, including pulmonic and mitral valve replacements, VSD and PFO closure, and tricuspid valve repair. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation, heart failure, diabetes, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Current conditions:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with a PCO2 in the 60s and baseline bicarb in the 40s. He is on oxygen therapy at home for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology of the acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but it is likely due to pneumonia (PNA) in the setting of COPD.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is unclear, and it is possible that he is hypovolemic or experiencing overdiuresis or hemoptysis. His cardiac output is uncertain due to the presence of a VSD and PFO.
3. MRSA PNA: The patient has MRSA in his sputum culture, and he is receiving vancomycin and cefepime.
4. Hemoptysis: The patient has grossly bloody material from his endotracheal tube, which may be due to intubation trauma or a more serious condition such as PNA, bronchiectasis, pulmonary AVM, or cancer.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension is likely worsening his right ventricular (RV) failure, which is also exacerbated by his congenital heart disease.
6. Cardiac rhythm: The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation, which is being rate-controlled.
7. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine is improving after a fluid bolus, and his urine electrolytes are consistent with a pre-renal etiology.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's serum sodium is low, and he is likely hypovolemic due to recent diuresis.
9. Eosinophilia: The patient has an absolute eosinophilia, which may be due to a drug eruption.
10. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, but it has resolved at OSH, and he is not receiving heparin, making hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) unlikely.
11. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and he is currently bleeding.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia progression: The patient's PNA may worsen and lead to sepsis or respiratory failure.
2. Right ventricular failure: The patient's worsening RV failure may lead to cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest.
3. Pulmonary hypertension exacerbation: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may worsen, leading to increased RV failure and decreased cardiac output.
4. Hemoptysis progression: The patient's hemoptysis may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or respiratory failure.
5. Acute kidney injury progression: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
6. Hyponatremia progression: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen, leading to seizures, coma, or death.
7. Eosinophilia progression: The patient's eosinophilia may worsen, leading to anaphylaxis or organ failure.
8. Thrombocytopenia progression: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or platelet dysfunction.
9. Anemia progression: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues or organ failure.

Based on these conditions and potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

**Medical History:**

* The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve.
* He has a history of CHF, DM, chronic afib, and multiple GIB.
* He is on coumadin and home oxygen therapy for presumed pulmonary hypertension.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is currently in the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia (PNA) in the setting of COPD.
* He has a history of hemoptysis, which is currently being managed with bronchial lavage and anticoagulation hold.
* His pulmonary hypertension is likely worsening, which may be contributing to his hypotension and RV failure.
* He has a history of chronic afib, which is currently being managed with rate control.
* He has anemia, eosinophilia, and thrombocytopenia, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly.
* Pneumonia: The patient's PNA may spread to other areas of the lungs, leading to worsening respiratory failure.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to a variety of factors, including hypovolemia, cardiogenic shock, or septic shock.
* RV failure: The patient's worsening RV failure may lead to cardiogenic shock.
* Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's worsening pulmonary hypertension may lead to further worsening of his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
* Infection: The patient's underlying medical conditions and recent antibiotic use may increase his risk of infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation hold may increase his risk of bleeding.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's acute hypercarbic respiratory failure will be managed with ventilation and bronchial lavage.
* His hemoptysis will be managed with bronchial lavage and anticoagulation hold.
* His pulmonary hypertension will be managed with dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60.
* His RV failure will be managed with dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60.
* His chronic afib will be managed with rate control.
* His anemia, eosinophilia, and thrombocytopenia will be monitored and managed as needed.
* His electrolyte imbalance will be managed with fluid boluses and electrolyte replacement.
* His diabetes will be managed with diet and medication as needed.
* His depression and anxiety will be managed with medication as needed.
* His nutrition will be managed with tube feeding and consultation with a nutritionist.
* His disposition will be continued in the ICU for now.

   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An

   - 1L NS bolus

   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, repaired valves, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and pulmonary hypertension. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, receiving oxygen therapy, and has a central venous catheter. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, eosinophilia, and thrombocytopenia. He is also experiencing anemia, hypercarbic respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia may worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and adjustment of ventilator settings are necessary.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or cardiogenic shock. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.
3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient's MRSA-positive sputum culture suggests that he may have developed pneumonia. Antibiotics should be continued, and further cultures should be taken to monitor for resistance.
4. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to trauma during intubation or an underlying lung condition. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and further evaluation are necessary to determine the cause and manage the condition.
5. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may worsen his respiratory status and cardiac function. Close monitoring of his cardiac status and further evaluation are necessary to determine the cause and manage the condition.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may be due to pre-renal etiology, and further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be due to hypovolemia, and further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.
8. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be due to a drug reaction, and further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to a bleeding disorder or medication, and further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.
10. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to bleeding or underlying medical condition, and further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and manage the condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue antibiotics for MRSA pneumonia and take further cultures to monitor for resistance.
3. Monitor the patient's hemoptysis and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary hypertension and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hyponatremia and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's eosinophilia and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and further evaluate to determine the cause and manage the condition.
10. Consider a nutrition consult to optimize the patient's nutritional status.

   mmol/L, Albumin:2.8 g/dL, LDH:199 IU/L, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL,
   PO4:3.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most [**Name (NI) 10842**] PNA.  No report of aspiration. Hypoxia
   improved with ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung
   parenchymal disease.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerated.  Patient is hypercarbic at baseline but
   appears to be hyperventilating at this time (alkalemic on last ABG with
   pCO2=43).  Will increase FiO2 in case oxygen drive is causing
   hyperventilation.
   .
   # Hypotension: Could be [**1-5**] hypovolemia +/- distributive shock.  CVP
   measured at 16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume
   status/preload.  No lactate to indicated hypoperfusion.  Patient has
   been repleted 5L since admission with substantial decrease in pressor
   requirement, as well as resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH.  Sputum cx here
   grew out coag + Staph, [**Last Name (un) **] pending.
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs.  No indications for atypical coverage at this time.
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   - suction / oral care as needed
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/CTX/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - resolving now off CTX/clindamycin
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - significantly improved since admission; ?drug rxn from abx
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # thrush
 noted to have thrush in mouth, on nystatin oral swishes.
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension. He was transferred to the ICU from the operating room after undergoing a surgical procedure. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 125/46 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96%. His cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.1 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 8.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 207 x 10^9/L. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.3 mmol/L and a sodium level of 135 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic atrial fibrillation, heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension. He is currently receiving treatment for hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and MRSA pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not treated promptly.
3. MRSA pneumonia: The patient's MRSA pneumonia can spread to other parts of the body and cause sepsis if not treated effectively.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension can worsen if not managed properly, leading to right ventricular failure and death.
5. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiogenic shock and death.
6. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding can worsen if not managed properly, leading to anemia and hemorrhagic shock.
7. Infection: The patient's infection can spread to other parts of the body and cause sepsis if not treated effectively.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's organ dysfunction can lead to multiple organ failure if not treated promptly.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications effectively.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9°C (100.2°F)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 88/45 mmHg (58/37 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Arterial blood gases: pH 7.42, PaCO2 51 mmHg, PaO2 90 mmHg

The patient has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime for MRSA pneumonia, and his respiratory status has improved. However, he remains hypercarbic at baseline.

The patient's hemodynamic status is concerning, with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 12 mmHg and a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg. He is currently off pressors, but his CVP may not accurately reflect his volume status due to a transducer error.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 244 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 32 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 140 mmol/L, potassium 4.3 mmol/L, chloride 105 mmol/L, bicarbonate 32 mmol/L

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and heart failure. He has undergone multiple surgeries, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of a ventricular septal defect and patent foramen ovale, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure
* Development of infective endocarditis
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Anemia and bleeding
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Hypotension and shock
* Thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
* Infection, including pneumonia and sepsis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing vancomycin and cefepime for MRSA pneumonia
* Weaning off pressors and monitoring for hypotension
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and thrombocytopenia
* Trending hemoglobin and platelet counts
* Continuing anticoagulation therapy
* Monitoring for signs of infection, including fever and leukocytosis
* Continuing respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
* Monitoring for signs of hypoxia and hypercarbia
* Trending electrolytes and blood urea nitrogen
* Monitoring for signs of kidney injury

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to the cardiovascular ICU.
